meanings.def: to place a dead body in the ground
examples: bury somebody/something They killed her and buried her body.
bury somebody/something + adv./prep. He was buried in Highgate Cemetery.
(figurative) Their ambitions were finally dead and buried.
The king is dead and lies buried at Jedburgh Abbey.
Those people are now all dead and buried.
She's 85 and has buried three husbands.

meanings.def: to hide something in the ground
examples: bury something We used to dig for hours, looking for buried treasure.
They plan to bury a time capsule containing work from every child in the school.
bury something + adv./prep. The dog had buried its bone in the garden.
The waste is buried deep underground.
He picked a berry from the bush.
Many people actually did bury treasure in the sand.

meanings.def: to cover somebody/something with soil, rocks, leaves, etc.
examples: bury somebody/something A landslide buried about 25 people yesterday.
bury somebody/something + adv./prep. The house was buried under ten feet of snow.
Another vehicle was found buried under rubble.
bury somebody/something + adj. The miners were buried alive when the tunnel collapsed.
The building was now buried under ten feet of soil.
He was buried up to his neck in sand.
a fallen tree trunk almost completely buried in the long grass

meanings.def: to cover something so that it cannot be seen
examples: Your letter got buried under a pile of papers.
He buried his face in his hands and wept.

meanings.def: to ignore or hide a feeling, a mistake, etc.
examples: She had learnt to bury her feelings.
her deeply buried pain
What secrets lie buried in the past?
Their ambitions were finally dead and buried.

meanings.def: to put something deeply into something else
examples: He walked slowly, his hands buried in his pockets.
She always has her head buried in a book.

meanings.def: to stop not being friendly and become friends again
examples: After not speaking to each other for years, the two brothers decided to bury the hatchet.

meanings.def: to refuse to admit that a problem exists or refuse to deal with it
to give the most important point of a news story near the end instead of at the beginning
examples: Unfortunately, he buried the lede in the last paragraph of the story.

idioms.idiom: bury the hatchet | bury your differences
idioms.def: to stop not being friendly and become friends again
examples: After not speaking to each other for years, the two brothers decided to bury the hatchet.

idioms.idiom: bury/hide your head in the sand
idioms.def: to refuse to admit that a problem exists or refuse to deal with it
to give the most important point of a news story near the end instead of at the beginning
examples: Unfortunately, he buried the lede in the last paragraph of the story.
